page.title: 03Ashurst: a description
page.content: North from the chalk of the South Downs the geological strata run in parallel bands - Greensand, Folkestone & Hythe Beds, then the Weald Clay; thick heavy and intractable when wet but fertile. Clay that once carried the great Andredleagh- a wood, according to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, once 120 miles long, east to west, and thirty miles broad, north to south. Our Domesday Survey area is solidly of this clay, broken by a re-entrant ridge of Hythe Beds fingering across the centre of the block, pointing west ending at Pepper's Farm. The village of Ashurst stands on this ridge. The ridge is split by a hardly noticable valley and its alluvium, cut by the River Adur which bows across the easternmost 3 km. column of this area.
